column2: pronounced [smêdereʋo] (listen)) is a city and the administrative center of the Podunavlje District in eastern Serbia. It is situated on the right bank of the Danube
column3: about 45 kilometres (28 miles) downstream of the Serbian capital

column2: the city has a population of 64
column5: 209 people living in its administrative area.

column1: Its history starts in the 1st century BC
column2: after the conquest of the Roman Empire
column3: when there existed a settlement by the name of Vinceia. The modern city traces its roots back to the late Middle Ages when it was the capital (1430–39
column4: and 1444–59) of the last independent Serbian state before Ottoman conquest.

column1: Smederevo is said to be the city of iron (Serbian: gvožđe) and grapes (grožđe).

column2: the city is known as Smederevo (Смедерево)
column3: in Latin
column6: in Hungarian as Szendrő or Vég-Szendrő

column1: The name of Smederevo was first recorded in the Charter of the Byzantine Emperor Basil II from 1019
column2: in the part related to the Eparchy of Braničevo (a suffragan diocese of the Archdiocese of Ochrid. Another written record is found in the Charter of Duke Lazar of Serbia from 1381
column3: by which he bestowed the Monastery of Ravanica and villages and properties 'to the Great Bogosav with the commune and heritage'’.

column1: The Latin-Italian name also occurs in Belogradum et Semendria and Belgrado e Semendria
column2: two of the short-lived 20th-century synonyms of the Latin titular bishopric of Belgrade
column3: which was suppressed in 1948 in favor of the residential Latin Archdiocese of Belgrade (Beograd) and 'newly' established titular bishopric of Alba marittima.

column1: Smederevo Coat of Arms uses two shades of blue
column2: which deviates from the heraldic principles (only one shade of every color
column3: contrasting those). Also
column4: the bar with the year 1430 is placed over the shield. Emblem elements are six white discs arranged 3 + 2 + 1
column7: dark blue and white horizontal lines (representing the Danube).

column2: the Starčevo culture existed for a millennia
column3: succeeded by the 6th millennium BC Vinča culture that prospered in the region. The Paleo-Balkan tribes of Dacians and Thracians emerged in the area in the 2nd millennia BC
column4: with the Celtic Scordisci raiding the Balkans in the 3rd century B.C.

column1: The Roman Empire conquered Vinceia in the 1st century BC. It was organized into Moesia
column2: later Moesia Superior
column3: and in the administrative reforms of Diocletian (244–311) it was part of the Diocese of Moesia
column4: then the Diocese of Dacia. It was a principal town of Moesia Superior
column5: near the confluence of Margus and Brongus rivers.

column1: The modern founder of the city was the Serbian Despot Đurađ Branković in the 15th century
column2: who built Smederevo Fortress in 1430 as the new Serbian capital. Smederevo was the residence of the Branković house and the capital of the Serbian Despotate from 1430 until 1439
column3: when it was conquered by the Ottoman Empire after a siege lasting two months.

column2: in accordance with the terms of the Peace of Szeged between the Kingdom of Hungary and the Ottoman Empire the Sultan returned Smederevo to Đurađ Branković
column3: who was allied to John Hunyadi. On 22 August 1444 the Serb prince peacefully took possession of the evacuated town. When Hunyadi broke the peace treaty
column4: Đurađ Branković remained neutral. Serbia became a battleground between the Kingdom of Hungary and the Ottomans
column5: and the angry Branković captured Hunyadi after his defeat at the Second Battle of Kosovo in 1448. Hunyadi was imprisoned in Smederevo fortress for a short time.

column1: In 1454 Sultan Mehmed II besieged Smederevo and devastated Serbia. The town was liberated by Hunyadi. In 1459 Smederevo was again captured by the Ottomans after the death of Branković. The town became a Turkish border-fortress
column2: and played an important part in Ottoman–Hungarian Wars until 1526. Due to its strategic location
column3: Smederevo was gradually rebuilt and enlarged. For a long period
column4: the town was the capital of the Sanjak of Smederevo.

column2: a joint army of Hungarians and Serbs tried to capture the fortress from the Ottomans. They built three wooden counter-fortresses
column3: but after months of siege Sultan Mehmed II himself came to drive them away. After fierce fighting the Hungarians agreed to withdraw. In 1494 Pál Kinizsi tried to capture Smederevo from the Ottomans but he was stricken with palsy and died. In 1512 John Zápolya unsuccessfully laid siege to the town.

column1: During the First Serbian Uprising in 1806
column2: the city became the temporary capital of Serbia
column3: as well as the seat of the Praviteljstvujušči sovjet
column4: a government headed by Dositej Obradović. The first basic school was founded in 1806. During World War II
column5: the city was occupied by German forces
column6: who stored ammunition in the fortress. On 5 June 1941
column7: a catastrophic explosion severely damaged the fortress

column2: Smederevo became an industrial and cultural center of Podunavlje district. Under the overall industrial development of Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia
column3: the city received a boost in infrastructure. Due to the ideal geographical position of Smederevo
column4: socialist government supported building of roads
column5: apartment buildings and tens of factories.

column1: Some of the most notable factories built and renewed in period between 1950s until the end of 1980s were Zelvoz (Heroj Srba during the period of SFRJ)
column2: renewed in 1966. and a new steel plant built on outskirts of Smederevo at that time
column3: Sartid (MKS during the period of SFRJ) which was completely operational in 1971.

column1: Smederevo has a recent history of heavy industry and manufacturing
column2: which is a result of intense industrialization of the region during the 1950s-1960s era. Previously
column3: this entire geographical region had a heavy focus on agricultural production.

column1: The city is home to the only operating steel mill in the country - Železara Smederevo
column2: previously known as Sartid
column3: which is situated in the suburb of Radinac. This was privatized and sold to U.S. Steel in 2003 for $33 million. Following the global economic crisis
column4: U.S. Steel sold the plant to the government of Serbia for a symbolic $1 to avoid closing the plant. The plant was renamed Železara Smederevo and at the time employed 5

column7: which purchased the effective assets for $46 million.The "Milan Blagojević" home appliance factory is the second largest industry company in the city. Smederevo is also an agricultural area
column8: with significant production of fruit and vines. However
column9: the large agricultural combine "Godomin" has been in financial difficulty since the 1990s and is almost defunct as of 2005. The grape variety known as Smederevka is named after the city. The "Ishrana" factory is an important supplier of bakery products in northern and eastern Serbia.A U.S.-Dutch consortium
column11: planned to build a $250 million oil refinery in the industrial zone of the city in 2012. However
column12: the consortium lost its permit to build the refinery after it failed to meet payment deadlines for the land lease a year later.As of September 2017
column13: Smederevo has one of 14 free economic zones established in Serbia.

column1: The river traffic infrastructure of the city of Smederevo consists of Danube waterway
column2: old port

column5: terminal for liquid Naftna Industrija Srbije loads
column6: as well as smaller piers (gravel pits) which are located along the bank in the industrial zone. The port is registered for international traffic and is located in the very center of the city of Smederevo.

column1: It has reloading capacities which can realize 1.5 million freight tons a year. By 2019

column1: Among the main tourist attractions in the city are the Smederevo Fortress and the Obrenović Villa.
